{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3489181,"name":"Neil","username":"neildell","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/e9bcb4/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-21T20:33:10.157Z","cooked":"

Hi all,

This is our first year designing an elevator for FRC, and we are wondering what the best way to make one is. The realistic options as of right now are 25 or 35 chain, or pullies. What is our best option?

Thanks for the help,
team 6975

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2025-01-21T20:33:10.157Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":38,"reads":212,"readers_count":211,"score":232.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":482922,"topic_slug":"elevator-pullies-or-chains","display_username":"Neil","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71619,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/elevator-pullies-or-chains/482922/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3489188,"name":"Oliver Kolodner","username":"OKolodner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/okolodner/{size}/242861_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-21T20:40:05.562Z","cooked":"

Chains. If those are the two options, chains are better, they have more strength, slip less, and because of both of those, you get better control. Some elevator options use constant tension springs and a winch mechanism, which is also a good option, but chain is definitely my favorite, plus there’s a ton of videos on making them, thrifty bot has a great assembly video for their elevator.

For your first year? I would go with 25 chain. Chain in general is far more forgiving than pullies/belts but your robot will be loud and a bit top heavy.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2025-01-21T20:45:45.012Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":177,"readers_count":176,"score":40.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":482922,"topic_slug":"elevator-pullies-or-chains","display_username":"Drakxii","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":23134,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2582/5941 Mentor, CSA, and RI "},"post_url":"/t/elevator-pullies-or-chains/482922/3","custom_user_title":"2582/5941 Mentor, CSA, and RI ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3489224,"name":"Patrick","username":"Patrick3357","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/patrick3357/{size}/169915_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-21T21:09:26.132Z","cooked":"

Chain is much heavier but slightly easier to work with simply because tensioners are a little simpler and you can more easily make any length of chain you could want. If you’re only driving a single stage of elevator with a chain, the simplicity might pay off, but I’d highly recommend using belt or rope for a continuous elevator or all but the first stage of a cascade elevator. a 3 stage elevator driven on both sides can easily use 30ft or more of chain or belt. At a minimum avoid the #35, its more than twice the weight.
